title: Ben Carson cleared of misconduct in furniture episode
text:
Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson. | Zach Gibson/Getty Images finance & tax Ben Carson cleared of misconduct in furniture episode

HUD Secretary Ben Carson has been cleared of misconduct allegations stemming from the 2017 purchase of a $31,561 dining table set for his office, according to an inspector general's report.

“We did not find sufficient evidence to substantiate allegations of misconduct on the part of Secretary Carson in connection with this procurement,” the inspector general said in a 14-page report posted Thursday.

Story Continued Below

Carson canceled the table order after it surfaced in news reports in early 2018, embarrassing him and sparking a public uproar. HUD spokespeople offered conflicting accounts of what Carson knew about the order, and he appeared to blame the fiasco on his wife, Candy, in congressional testimony.

But the IG said, “We found no evidence indicating that either Secretary or Mrs. Carson exerted improper influence on any departmental employee in connection with the procurement.”

The order “initially went forward because career officials … determined that the existing dining room furniture set in the secretarial suite was in poor condition, that it could not be repaired, and that it should be replaced,” the IG found.

Carson said he was “so disgusted” with the “narrative” surrounding the order, in an interview earlier Thursday with Fox Business.

“The IG’s report demonstrates, as I have said all along, that I had very little to do with the whole story,” he said. “There's probably no one in Washington who cares less about furniture than I do.”

HUD declined to comment on the report beyond pointing to that interview.

The Government Accountability Office earlier this year found that Carson broke the law when he ordered the table set for his office and spent over $8,000 to install a dishwasher in his office kitchen without providing advance notice to congressional appropriators.

Agencies are required to notify Congress of an expenditure over $5,000 to furnish an executive’s office.

“The fact that evidently no one involved in this procurement had such awareness [of that requirement] indicates a systemic failure,” the IG concluded, noting that HUD has “historically lacked effective internal controls to ensure that purchases for presidentially-appointed officials comply with the law.”

Ultimately, the IG is not making any recommendations to HUD, the report said, in part because “the Department is working to address the legal ramifications of the dining-room-furniture procurement and to prevent future appropriations-law violations.”
